defs.name: HashCommitment
defs.docs:
calculate commitment c = H(m,r) using SHA3 CRHF.
 r is 256bit blinding factor, m is the commited value

defs.name: PedersenCommitment
defs.docs:
compute c = mG + rH
 where m is the commited value, G is the group generator,
 H is a random point and r is a blinding value.

defs.name: HomoELGamalProof
defs.docs:
This is a proof of knowledge that a pair of group elements {D, E}
 form a valid homomorphic ElGamal encryption (”in the exponent”) using public key Y .
 (HEG is defined in B. Schoenmakers and P. Tuyls. Practical Two-Party Computation Based on the Conditional Gate)
 Specifically, the witness is ω = (x, r), the statement is δ = (G, H, Y, D, E).
 The relation R outputs 1 if D = xH+rY , E = rG (for the case of G=H this is ElGamal)

attributes.value: / This is a proof of knowledge that a pair of group elements {D, E}
/ form a valid homomorphic ElGamal encryption (”in the exponent”) using public key Y .
/ (HEG is defined in B. Schoenmakers and P. Tuyls. Practical Two-Party Computation Based on the Conditional Gate)
/ Specifically, the witness is ω = (x, r), the statement is δ = (G, H, Y, D, E).
/ The relation R outputs 1 if D = xH+rY , E = rG (for the case of G=H this is ElGamal)

defs.name: HomoElGamalStatement
defs.value: HomoElGamalStatement { G, H, Y, D, E }

attributes.value: allow(non_snake_case)

defs.docs:
This is a proof of knowledge that a pair of group elements {D, E}
 form a valid homomorphic ElGamal encryption (”in the exponent”) using public key Y .
 (HEG is defined in B. Schoenmakers and P. Tuyls. Practical Two-Party Computation Based on the Conditional Gate)
 Specifically, the witness is ω = (x, r), the statement is δ = (G, Y, Q, D, E).
 The relation R outputs 1 if D = xG+rY , E = rG, Q = xG

defs.name: DLogProof
defs.docs:
This is implementation of Schnorr's identification protocol for elliptic curve groups or a
 sigma protocol for Proof of knowledge of the discrete log of an Elliptic-curve point:
 C.P. Schnorr. Efficient Identification and Signatures for Smart Cards. In
 CRYPTO 1989, Springer (LNCS 435), pages 239–252, 1990.
 https://pdfs.semanticscholar.org/8d69/c06d48b618a090dd19185aea7a13def894a5.pdf.

attributes.value: / This is implementation of Schnorr's identification protocol for elliptic curve groups or a
/ sigma protocol for Proof of knowledge of the discrete log of an Elliptic-curve point:
/ C.P. Schnorr. Efficient Identification and Signatures for Smart Cards. In
/ CRYPTO 1989, Springer (LNCS 435), pages 239–252, 1990.
/ https://pdfs.semanticscholar.org/8d69/c06d48b618a090dd19185aea7a13def894a5.pdf.
/ The protocol is using Fiat-Shamir Transform: Amos Fiat and Adi Shamir.
/ How to prove yourself: Practical solutions to identification and signature problems.
/ In Advances in Cryptology - CRYPTO ’86, Santa Barbara, California, USA, 1986, Proceedings,

defs.name: ECDDHProof
defs.docs:
This protocol is the elliptic curve form of the protocol from :
  D. Chaum, T. P. Pedersen. Transferred cash grows in size. In Advances in Cryptology, EUROCRYPT , volume 658 of Lecture Notes in Computer Science, pages 390 - 407, 1993.
  This is a proof of membership of DDH: (G, xG, yG, xyG)
 The statement is (G1,H1, G2, H2), the witness is x. The relation outputs 1 if :
 H1 = xG1, H2 = xG2
 The protocol:
 1: Prover chooses A1 = s*G1 , A2 = sG2  for random s1,s2
 prover calculates challenge e = H(G1,H1,G2,H2,A1,A2)
 prover calculates z  = s + ex,
 prover sends pi = {e, A1,A2,z}

attributes.value: / This protocol is the elliptic curve form of the protocol from :
/  D. Chaum, T. P. Pedersen. Transferred cash grows in size. In Advances in Cryptology, EUROCRYPT , volume 658 of Lecture Notes in Computer Science, pages 390 - 407, 1993.
/  This is a proof of membership of DDH: (G, xG, yG, xyG)
/ The statement is (G1,H1, G2, H2), the witness is x. The relation outputs 1 if :
/ H1 = xG1, H2 = xG2
/ The protocol:
/ 1: Prover chooses A1 = s*G1 , A2 = sG2  for random s1,s2
/ prover calculates challenge e = H(G1,H1,G2,H2,A1,A2)
/ prover calculates z  = s + ex,
/ prover sends pi = {e, A1,A2,z}
/ verifier checks that zG1 = A1 + eH1, zG2 = A2 + eH2

defs.name: PedersenProof
defs.docs:
protocol for proving that Pedersen commitment c was constructed correctly which is the same as
 proof of knowledge of (m,r) such that c = mG + rH.
 witness: (m,r), statement: c, The Relation R outputs 1 if c = mG + rH. The protocol:
 1: Prover chooses A1 = s1*G , A2 = s2*H for random s1,s2
 prover calculates challenge e = H(G,H,c,A1,A2)
 prover calculates z1  = s1 + em, z2 = s2 + er
 prover sends pi = {e, A1,A2,c, z1,z2}

attributes.value: / protocol for proving that Pedersen commitment c was constructed correctly which is the same as
/ proof of knowledge of (m,r) such that c = mG + rH.
/ witness: (m,r), statement: c, The Relation R outputs 1 if c = mG + rH. The protocol:
/ 1: Prover chooses A1 = s1*G , A2 = s2*H for random s1,s2
/ prover calculates challenge e = H(G,H,c,A1,A2)
/ prover calculates z1  = s1 + em, z2 = s2 + er
/ prover sends pi = {e, A1,A2,c, z1,z2}
/ verifier checks that z1*G + z2*H  = A1 + A2 + ec

defs.name: PedersenBlindingProof
defs.docs:
protocol for proving that Pedersen commitment c was constructed correctly which is the same as
 proof of knowledge of (r) such that c = mG + rH.
 witness: (r), statement: (c,m), The Relation R outputs 1 if c = mG + rH. The protocol:
 1: Prover chooses A = s*H for random s
 prover calculates challenge e = H(G,H,c,A,m)
 prover calculates z  = s + er,
 prover sends pi = {e, m,A,c, z}
 verifier checks that emG + zH  = A + ec

attributes.value: / protocol for proving that Pedersen commitment c was constructed correctly which is the same as
/ proof of knowledge of (r) such that c = mG + rH.
/ witness: (r), statement: (c,m), The Relation R outputs 1 if c = mG + rH. The protocol:
/ 1: Prover chooses A = s*H for random s
/ prover calculates challenge e = H(G,H,c,A,m)
/ prover calculates z  = s + er,
/ prover sends pi = {e, m,A,c, z}
/ verifier checks that emG + zH  = A + ec
allow(non_snake_case)

defs.name: VerifiableSS
defs.docs:
Feldman VSS, based on  Paul Feldman. 1987. A practical scheme for non-interactive verifiable secret sharing.
 In Foundations of Computer Science, 1987., 28th Annual Symposium on.IEEE, 427–43

attributes.value: / Feldman VSS, based on  Paul Feldman. 1987. A practical scheme for non-interactive verifiable secret sharing.
/ In Foundations of Computer Science, 1987., 28th Annual Symposium on.IEEE, 427–43
/ implementation details: The code is using FE and GE. Each party is given an index from 1,..,n and a secret share of type FE.
/ The index of the party is also the point on the polynomial where we treat this number as u32 but converting it to FE internally.

defs.name: coin_flip_optimal_rounds
defs.docs:
This is an implementation of string coin tossing of a string, to generate a random string between
two non-trusting parties. Based on the
 the protocol and proof analysis  in "How To Simulate It – A Tutorial on the Simulation
 Proof Technique∗" (https://eprint.iacr.org/2016/046.pdf)

defs.name: dh_key_exchange
defs.docs:
This is an implementation of a Diffie Hellman Key Exchange.
 Party1 private key is "x",
 Party2 private key is "y",
 The shared secret is Q = xyG

attributes.value: /This is an implementation of a Diffie Hellman Key Exchange.

/ Party2 private key is "y",
/ The shared secret is Q = xyG

defs.name: dh_key_exchange_variant_with_pok_comm
defs.docs:
This is an implementation of a Diffie Hellman Key Exchange.
 Party1 private key is "x",
 Party2 private key is "y",
protocol:
 party1 sends a commitmemt to P1 = xG a commitment to a proof of knowledge of x
 party2 sends P2 and a proof of knowledge of y
 party1 verifies party2 proof decommit to P1 and  to the PoK
 party2 verifies party1 proof
 the shared secret is Q = xyG
 reference can be found in protocol 3.1 step 1 - 3(b) in the paper https://eprint.iacr.org/2017/552.pdf

attributes.value: /This is an implementation of a Diffie Hellman Key Exchange.

/ party1 sends a commitmemt to P1 = xG a commitment to a proof of knowledge of x
